slides.name: Collecting the e-prime data
description: This will cover the steps taken to set up the delivery of the e-prime scripts in the lab
This will also cover delivering the rest of the protocol minus the psychophys which is covered separately
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Tracking completed steps
description: Use the 'Checklist' to track your progress in setting up the lab for each participant
Printed copies are in the black letter trays in the lab
On SharePoint found in 'Printed' under '2020 Document and Protocol'

slides.name: Setting up protocol folders
description: The four protocol folders (one for each condition) are located on the right hand wall as you enter
The materials are in the black letter trays (ethics, goal ratings, rumination ratings)
To replenish and store the materials see the separate tutorial
Completed materials are stored in the locked cabinet in the MDC group office
Select the folder corresponding to the participant condition
Add in the relavent paper files to the corresponding page and then place in the lab

slides.name: Setting up lab computer
description: The control computers for lab 133b are at the back on the left as you go into 133b
The E-prime computer is the one on the left
The password is 'mangochutney'
The folders you need are on the desktop
There is a general 'BA Grant' folder which contains all the files and then inidivual folders for each condition
The condition folders are named by condition and the color of the corresponding file
Open the folder for the participants condition
Check that the computer in the lab is showing the screen

slides.name: Backing up data
description: The files in the condition folders are shortcuts to the live files inside 'BA Grant'
Therefore all generated data will be in the 'Live' Folder
At the end of the data transfer the data into participant folders inside 'Data'
Then back the participant files up onto the harddrive and sharepoint (see separate tutorial)

slides.name: Psychophys preprocessing part 1
description: This slideshow goes through the steps for part 1 of the preprocessing
The purpose of part 1 is to generate the beats (QRS peaks) per minute across the experiment
First we will apply a filter to the heart rate (ECG) data and then we can identify all the QRS peaks to calculate BPM
For further information, please speak to Anke and/or view the pdfs in the 'BiopacDA' folder on sharepoint/harddrive
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Step 1 - Open file in AcqKnowledge
description: Open AcqKnowledge 5.0 (you will need dongle)
Open the raw file to be processed
To demonstrate the process we will be using participant 1

slides.name: Step 2 - Filter the data
description: The first step is to filter the heart rate to remove noise
Firstly, ensure you have the ECG channel (7) highlighted
Click 'Transform'
Click 'Digital Filter
Click 'FIR' then 'Band Pass'

slides.name: Step 3 - Apply the filter
description: We will apply a filter between 0.5 and 35 Hz, using 8000 coefficients, therefore
For 'Low Frequency Cutoff' click 'Fixed at' and type in '0.5'
For 'High Frequency Cutoff' click 'Fixed at' and type in '35'
For 'Number of Coefficiants' click 'Fixed at' and type in '8000'
Click 'Ok'

slides.name: Step 4 - Filtering
description: The filter then will be applied generating a new filtered ECG channel (3)
The next preprocessing step is to run a script to identify all the ECG peaks
However first we will save this as a new preprocessed file

slides.name: Step 5 - Save
description: Save the file in the preprocessed folder
Name the file with the participant number followed by the letter 'p'

slides.name: Step 6 - Open MarkandClean script
description: Now we will run the script which helps identify the QRS peaks
Click 'Script'
Click 'Script Editor'
Then click 'File' and 'Open...
Open the 'MarkandClean' script

slides.name: Step 7 - Run MarkandClean script
description: Click 'Run'
You will then be asked a series of questions:
Click 'no' to 'Does your graph have a visible journal?'
Click the filtered ECG channel (3)
Click 'no' to the question 'Should I apply a 0.5 Hz high pass filter?'
Click 'continue'

slides.name: Step 8 - Highlight typical QRS peak
description: As instructed we first need to give the algorithm a typical peak
Zoom in to get a good view of a peak
Click the cursor tool
Highlight a QRS peak
Click 'Peak is selected'

slides.name: Step 9 - Checking the algorithm
description: Click 'Ok'
You will now be asked to check the algorithm has correctly identified the first six peaks
In this case all the 'qrs' labels are correctly placed so we will answer 'yes'
If you answer no, you will then get a chance to place the 'qrs' labels correctly
The algorithm will now be run to identify the peaks and then it will evaluate the average distance between peaks (IBI)
You will then be shown each shorter/longer than average distance in turn to check whether the 'qrs' label is correctly placed

slides.name: Step 10 - Investigating short gaps between peaks
description: First you will be shown each shorter than average IBI to evaluate whether the peaks have been placed correctly
To remove a 'qrs' label, ensure this is selected and click 'Remove Selected Event'
If a 'qrs' lavel is in the wrong place, press down 'Alt' and move the 'qrs' to the correct location
If the 'qrs' peaks are correct, click 'Ignore this Short IBI'
In this case the displayed 'qrs' labels are correctly placed so we will click ignore
Keep doing this until a new pop up appears
If at any point you are not sure do send screenshots to Anke

slides.name: Step 11 - Investigating long gaps between peaks
description: Now you will be shown each longer than average IBI to evaluate whether any peaks have been missed
To add a 'qrs' label, ensure the cursor is on the peak click 'Add Event at Selected Peak'
If a 'qrs' label is in the wrong place, press down 'alt' and move the 'qrs' to the correct location
If the 'qrs' peaks are correct, click 'Ignore this Long IBI'
Ensure you scroll either side of the peak to check the distance
In this case the displayed 'qrs' labels are correctly placed so we will click ignore
Keep doing this until you get a box in the middle of the screen, click 'continue'

slides.name: Step 12 - Create beats per minute channel
description: Click 'yes'
The script will now create a new bpm channel (4)
In part 2 you will extract the average bpm for each task
You will be given the option to save click 'no' for now

slides.name: Step 13 - Check new bpm channel
description: The final step of part 1 is to examine the new bpm channel to double-check the algorithm output
For this you will need to zoom in on channel 3 and 4
You can remove uneccesary channels by selecting then while holding down 'Alt'
Examine the entire bpm for any jaggedly lines
If there are any jaggedly lines, then it is likely a 'qrs' peak is missing and you may need to rerun the script

slides.name: Step 14 - Finish and save
description: When you are happy the peaks are correctly labelled, save your work
That is the end of part 1
In part 2, we will extract the mean heart rate (and skin conductance) and heart rate variability to excel

slides.name: Psychophys preprocessing part 2
description: This slideshow goes through the steps for part 2 of the preprocessing
The purpose of part 1 is to output the heart rate and skin condunctance for each of the tasks
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Step 1 - Open file
description: Open processed file e.g. '1p'
We are now going to extract the mean heart rate and skin conductance for each of the interested tasks
We will also extract the minimum and maximum skin conductance
We first need to tell Acqknowledge which timepoints correspond to each of the interested tasks
To do this we can create 'focus areas'

slides.name: Step 2 - Show selection palette
description: First we need to display the 'Selection Palette' and 'Show Focus Area' tools
Click 'Display' then 'Show'
Click 'Selection Palette'

slides.name: Step 3 - Show Focus Areas
description: You should now see the selection palette with the currently highlighted area
Repeat the process to also show the focus areas

slides.name: Step 4 - Baseline Focus Area
description: Zoom in over the first trigger peak - the baseline
Place the cursor at the beginning of the peak
Then in the 'Right' input box on the selection palette add 5 minutes
This should then highlight all the baseline pick
Then click the dropdown arrow to the right
Click 'Create Focus Area'
Then type in 'Baseline' as the focus area label

slides.name: Step 5 - SART Practice Focus Area
description: Now if you click outside the selection, you should still the 'Baseline' focus area in pink
The next timepoint of interest is the practice SART task
Again place your cursor at the beginning of the next peak
This time add 1 minute to the right selection palette
Create a new focus area with label 'SART practice'

slides.name: Step 6 - Audio Focus Area
description: The next task we want data for is the audio recording
Skip the next peak over the goal focus recording and place your cursor at the beginning of the audio peak (~35mins)
We can only make analysis over whole minutes so add 9 minutes for this selection
There will be some recording not selected that is fine
Again create focus area this time called 'Audio'

slides.name: Step 7 - SART Focus Areas
description: The SART analysis is being performed for the first 30 minutes
This 30 minutes is being broken up into 9 time windows
The first 10 minutes is in 1 minute focus areas:
SART 1min, SART 2min, SART 3min, SART 4min, SART 5min, SART 6min,SART 7min, SART 8min, SART 9min, SART 10min
Then the remaining 20 minutes is split up into 5 minute focus areas:
SART 15min, SART 20min, SART 25min, SART 30min
Start the first selection at the beginning of the peak and then add 1/5 minutes updating the left and right selection palette each time
When you're done your screen should look like the image

slides.name: Step 8 - Check Focus Areas
description: Zoom out to view the whole collection
Before we start the analysis, just double check that all the focus areas are correct
To make any necessary edits use the 'Focus Area Bar'
Again you can find this in 'Display' then 'Show'
To delete a focus area, press the '-'
To rename a focus area, press the '...'

slides.name: Step 9 - Extracting means
description: Now we will extract the means (and min and max for SCR) into excel for each focus area
Click 'Analysis'
Click 'Epoch Analysis'

slides.name: Step 10 - Epoch Analysis
description: Change Epoch width to 60 seconds'
At the bottom for 'Analyze' click 'focus areas only'
Then For 'Locate epochs at:' click 'fixed time intervals'
Ensure 'Start first epoch at:' is 'left edge of focus area'
Change 'Time between epochs' to 0 seconds
Change 'Output type' to 'Excel Spreadsheet Only
Click 'OK'

slides.name: Step 11 - Data to extract
description: Now we tell the software which data to extract
Click 'Add..'
Select 'Mean' and click 'OK'
Select the BPM channel (4)
Repeat the above for 'Mean' of the SCR channel (6)
Repeat the above for 'Min' of the SCR channel (6)
Repeat the above for 'Max' of the SCR channel (6)
Your screen should match the image and then click 'Ok'

slides.name: Step 12 - Means Spreadsheet
description: The software will now conduct the analysis and export it to excel
Check through the file ensuring that data looks good
E.g. check the heart rate is between ~60-120bpm
Save the resulting spreadsheet in 'Output' with the file number
Add a new sheet and call it 'HRV'
Leave this file open to come back to

slides.name: Step 13 - Further heart rate analysis
description: Keep the excel file open and go back to AcqKnowledge
Firstly go into the Journal (box at the bottom) and delete the contents (you will get an error in the next step otherwise)
Then click 'Analysis'
Click 'HRV and RSA
Click 'Multi-epoch HRV and RSA - Spectral

slides.name: Step 14 - HRV spectral analysis
description: Ensure the ECG channel is selected (3)
Change 'Extract HRV and RSA for' to 'Focus Areas'
Change 'Output type' to 'Excel Spreadsheet Only'
Click 'OK'

slides.name: Step 15 - HRV spreadsheet
description: The programme will now run the analysis and export to a second excel spreadsheet
Now we can merge the two spreadsheets together

slides.name: Step 16 - Merge spreadsheets
description: Copy and paste the HRV data into the 'HRV' sheet you created on the means column
Then add in the 'Time window' column to label the time windows
You can automate this using the 'PsychophysOutput' macro
Save the means spreadsheet and back up (you can discard the HRV one)
This is the end of part 2

slides.name: E-prime preprocessing
description: This tutorial outlines the preprocessing steps for the data collected on E-Prime
These are the PANAS, SART, goal practice task and writing tasks
The files for these are under 'eprime' on sharepoint
The majority of this will need to be done on a university computer with E-Prime installed
Click 'next' to get started

slides.name: PANAS
description: Open the excel file called 'PANAS'
This document is currently laid out to allow a direct copy and paste from the e.dat files
Need to add in labelling to know which question is which
Open the e.dat file and copy over the PANAS column for each time point
Once this is complete you will be able to 'copy' and 'transpose' to get this laid out with participant as rows and the data as columns

slides.name: Writing Tasks
description: Open the excel file called 'Writing tasks'
Like the PANAS this is a direct copy and paste from the e.dat files.
Use 'find' and 'replace' to remove all the extra characters
E.g. find '{SPACE}' and replace with ' '

slides.name: SART
description: For the SART you will need to export the e.dat files into excel
Export as a text file into 'raw text' which you can then open in excel
Open the text file in excel and save as excel macro enabled workbook into 'raw excel'
You can automate this process using the 'SARTConvertFileType' macro
The next step is to clean up this file and output thought probes, accuracy and reaction time data

slides.name: SART p1 - SART clean and analyse macro
description: Open the raw excel file and run the 'SARTCleanandAnalyse' macro
Click 'Run' and then 'Ok'
The macro does a couple of odd things for the reaction time data so there are a couple of quick tweaks to make

slides.name: SART p2 - Removing pesky '@' symbol for filter
description: In order to calculate the reaction time results, there are a couple of edits to make
The macro does a couple of odd things so there are a couple of quick tweaks that need making before you get the results
Firstly, on the 'GoTrials' sheet in cell A2 remove the '@' symbol before 'FILTER'
This should then populate this sheet

slides.name: SART p3 - Adjust RT for correct go trials rows
description: If you go next to the 'Results' tab, you will see the RT mean and SD calculation defaults to the maximum possible number of rows '2:1351'
This needs individually adjusting according to each participants performance, adjust ththe range to the exact number of rows in 'GoTrials' (this should be equal to the number in 'Results!H2' + 1)
Adjust the range for BOTH the MEAN and SD and those are the results
Save your work

slides.name: SART p4 - Consolidate results
description: Once you have made the adjustments to the macro output for the reaction time (previous 2 slides), you can now add the data to the 'SART' spreadsheet on SharePoint
Open the file inside '2020 Data/eprime/SART'
In a new row, add in the participant ID into the first column, then copy and paste the data from the 'Results' tab you just created

slides.name: Collecting the psychophys data
description: This will cover the steps taken to set up the lab for the psychophys recordings
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Tracking completed steps
description: Use the 'Checklist' to track your progress in setting up the lab for each participant
Printed copies are in the black letter trays in the lab
On SharePoint found in 'Printed' under '2020 Document and Protocol'

slides.name: Setting up BIOPAC
description: Enter the testing room 133b and find the BIOPAC machine at the back
Turn on the machine by pressing the button at the back on the left inwards
Switch air conditioning on

slides.name: Setting up computer
description: The control computers are back out in the main room at the back on the left
The computer on the right is the Acqknowledge/BIOPAC machine
Switch this computer on (ensure you do this after turning the BIOPAC on)
The password is 'eeg'
There is a folder on the desktop called 'BA Grant'
This folder contains the template graph and a folder called 'Data' with the data in
Open Acknowledge

slides.name: Setting up AcqKnowledge
description: Open the template graph so that you can see channels for the ECG (heart rate), SCR (skin conductance) and trigger
Save as a new file in 'BA Grant/Data' with the participant number
As the experiment runs you will likely need to recenter the SCR vertically using the outlined button
To zoom out and view the whole experiment on screen click the button to the right

slides.name: Changing the acquisition time
description: The default collection length is 30minutes with AcqKnowledge so the recording will stop during the experiment
To do this, click 'MP160'
Then click 'Set Up Data Aquisition...
Increase the 'Aquisition Time' to '7200' seconds
Then you can close the window
When you are have placed the sensors on the participant and are ready to begin recording, press 'Start'

slides.name: Sensors
description: The heart rate sensors are disposable and stored in the cupboard on the left as you enter the main 133 room
You will need two for each participant
Place these, the alcohol and the Q-tips in the testing room ready
The skin conductance sensors are washed between participants and will be on the drying rack by the sink
Collect one (of two) of these wires and plug into the BIOPAC machine in channel 6 (no tape goes in middle)
Instructions for placing the sensors on the participant are in the protocol folder (and speak to Anke)

slides.name: End of testing
description: After each participant, unplug the sensors, bin the heart rate and wash the skin conductance
At the end of the day, turn off machines and the air conditioning
Then back the participant files up onto the harddrive and sharepoint (see separate tutorial)
You will likely have to do this via memory stick as the machine did not recognise harddrive

slides.name: Getting starting with Qualtrics
description: The following information details how to login and navigate around Qualtrics
This outlines the basic use of Qualtrics for the screening survey for part 1 of the study.
After this, for more information on extracting the data see separate tutorial
For more information see the Qualtrics support pages (link on home page)
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Logging in
description: Navigate to the Exeter CLES Qualtrics login site
Input username and password
Use my login details until you add yourself

slides.name: Project List
description: Signing in you get navigated to the list of projects. Click on 'BA Grant Project'

slides.name: Project Page
description: This is the page when you can edit the screener
The blocks of the questionnaires are listed in the order they appear
Inside 'Info and consent' is the participant generated 'id' question allowing you to identify the survey responses once you delete the contact information for anonymity on SharePoint
'Survey Flow' details the order in which participants view the pages of the site including the set up of exclusions
The following pages will go over the 'Actions' and 'Data & Analysis' tabs for details on the emails sent out by Qualtrics and how you can view and export data
You should not need any of the other buttons but instructions are on the support pages which there is a link to on the home page

slides.name: Actions
description: This is the page where the automated emails are set up and monitored
There is one email sent to participants that are 'included' as a reminder for their lab session
There is another email sent participants who are 'excluded' which is cc'd to Nick
For both email taks you will need to add your email address to be alerted by clicking on the email task (multiple emails are separated with a comma)

slides.name: Data & Analysis
description: This is the page when you can view and download the data
To change the columns you can preview, click on 'Tools' and then 'Choose Columns
For instructions on how to do download the data and add to SharePoint, continue onto the separate tutorial

slides.name: Logging Out
description: To logout, click on the icon top right and press 'Logout'

slides.name: Guide to data storage
description: The following information details the storage of data
This includes SharePoint, the harddrives, the lab and the cabinent in the MDC group office
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Paper files
description: Paper materials include the information sheet, consent forms, checklist for testing and the goal and rumination ratings
These are found on sharepoint in 'Printed' in '2020 Documents and Protocol
The uncompleted printed materials are stored in the lab in the black letter trays
Completed materials are stored in the locked cabinet in MDC group office
The files are currently stored by document rather than by participant
i.e. consent forms are on separate shelf, one wallet contains checklists, one wallet contains goal ratings and another wallet contains

slides.name: Harddrives and dongle
description: The two harddrives and dongle for AcqKnowledge are stored with the paper files in the locked cabinet in MDC group office
I use just one harddrive for backing up files
Once a week, add new files onto the second hardddrive

slides.name: E-prime and psychophys
description: At the end of the day, all raw data from the EEG and psychophys computer needs uploading to sharepoint
Lab computers are not connected to network therefore this is via hard drive (or memory stick for psychophys computer)
This also means the harddrive contains back up of data too
You will need to first move the eprime files from the live versions into a participant folder under 'Data'
On my laptop, I then copy the memory stick files over onto the harddrive and then all files are uploaded into raw files on sharepoint

slides.name: Goal and rumination ratings
description: The hardcopies of the ratings are stored in the cabinet
The hardcopies need scanning and imported into the 'scans' folder on Sharepoint
The data also needs entering into the 'Problem ratings' spreadsheet on SharePoint

slides.name: Exporting Data from Qualtrics
description: The following information details how to export data from Qualtrics
It also covers cleaning up the excel file ready to add to sharepoint
If you are new to Qualtrics, please view the introductory slides first
For more information see the Qualtrics support pages
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Step 1 - Login to Qualtrics
description: Login to Qualtrics (click link in header)
Click on 'BA Grant Project' to navigate to project page

slides.name: Step 2 - Navigate to Data & Analysis
description: This is the page when you can edit the screener
For more information visit the qualtrics support pages (link in footer)
To view and export collect data, click on the 'Data & Analysis' tab

slides.name: Step 3 - Viewing collected responses
description: This is the page when you can view and download the data
To change the columns you can preview, click on 'Tools' and then 'Choose Columns

slides.name: Step 4 - Downloading collected responses
description: To download the responses into excel, click 'Export and Import' and then 'Export data...'

slides.name: Step 4 - Downloading excel file
description: Use the default tab to download as 'csv' file
Keep 'Download all fields' selected. (You will need to remove the contact fields from the download manually)
Select 'Use Numerical Values'
Click 'Download' to download

slides.name: Step 5 - Editing columns
description: Open the downloaded excel file
Delete the columns containing personally identifying information
These are: 'Status', 'IPAddress', 'LocationLatitude', 'LocationLongitude', 'name' and 'email'
The responses can still be identified using the 'id' (and as a back up by logging onto Qualtrics)

slides.name: Step 6 - Updating sharepoint data
description: Open the 'Qualtrics Export' file on SharePoint in '2020 Data' under 'qualtrics'
Identify the timepoint of your last update and find this row in the new download
Copy and paste data below this point into the sharepoint file (columns in grey are manually added)
Ensure the data fields match up (if not you have probably not deleted enough columns)

The 'id' column is a direct copy of the 'id' field from Qualtrics (FYI those in red are abbrievated from the ResponseID as these participants completed Qualtrics prior to adding of the participant generated id question)
The 'ID' and Condition' need adding in once participant has attended the lab session

slides.name: Macros
description: There are various excel and Acqknowledge macros to make the preprocessing more efficient
These are all within the 'Macros' folder in '2020 data' on SharePoint
They are also on the first harddrive 'BA Grant 1'
This tutorial will go through using the excel macros I created (.bas)
For the AcqKnowledge macro (.bbs), see the separate psychophys preprocessing tutorials

slides.name: Part 1 - Excel macros
description: When to use each macro will be covered by the preprocessing tutorials but this will go through how to download and run the excel macros (.bas) on your device.
First go onto sharepoint and download the macros onto your machine
Alternatively you can use the files on the harddrive
To run the macros, you first need to import them into excel
Open excel

slides.name: Part 2 - Enabling developer tools
description: To run the macros onto your device, you will need to enable 'Developer' tools in excel
To do this open excel and click 'File'
Click 'Options' bottom left
Then click 'Customise Ribbon'
In 'Customise the Ribbon' on the right down scroll down to 'Developer' and check the box
Click 'Ok'

slides.name: Part 3 - Macros and creating PERSONAL workbook
description: Macros are usually stored in the current open workbook
It is also possible to store them in the PERSONAL workbook which is available to any excel workbooks opened on your device.
We first need to open the PERSONAL workbook
You will now be able to access the 'Developer' tab
Click'Developer'
Click 'Record Macro'
You do not need to give this macros a specific name or shortcut
Ensure you select 'Personal Macro Workbook' as the place to store macro in

slides.name: Part 5  - Visual Basic
description: Now to import the files into your newly created PERSONAL workbook we now need to open the code editor 'Visual Basic'
You do not need to write any code to do this
You should only have to do this once

slides.name: Part 4  - Importing macros
description: use 'File' and 'Import File...' to import each macro
Drag and drop the files into 'Modules' under 'VBAProject (PERSONAL.XLSB)
You can delete your macro you just created by right clicking on it and then clicking 'Remove Macro1'
When you are done your files should match the image (your code may be formatted differently)
You can now close visual basic

slides.name: Part 5 - Running a macro
description: To run the macro, on the 'Developer' tab click 'Macros'
Then select the macro you wish to use and click 'Run'
When running the macros ensure you have the correct sheet open

slides.name: Navigation around SharePoint
description: The following information details how to navigate around sharepoint
After this, see separate slides on introductions to the e-prime and psychophys data
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Sharepoint
description: This quick tutorial will give an intro into the files on sharepoint
Do click on 'Documents' first to access files
The latest materials are in '2020 Documents and Protocol
The data collected and preprocessed so far is in '2020 Data'

slides.name: 2020 Documents and Protocol
description: 'E-prime Scripts' - the files on the lab computer in 'Live Versions' are the most up to date so this folder needs updating
'Printed' - these are the materials that need printing for each participant (ethics materials, goal and rumination ratings)
The rest of the files include the tasks programmed into e-prime (e.g. writing tasks)
This includes the mp3 files that are used in the audio induction
There is also document detailing the advert up on SONA and the emails sent out from Qualtrics

slides.name: 2020 Data
description: 'Participants' contains the log of participants and a record of pre-processing steps
The 'eprime' folder contains the raw e.dat files and preprocessed excel files for the tasks completed on e-prime (goal practice task, PANAS, SART, writing tasks)
The 'macros' folder contains the macros I have created to pre-process the psychophys and SART data for your reference
The 'psychophys' folder contains the raw and pre-processed files from Acknowledge, as well as excel output files
The 'qualtrics' folder contains the export of the part 1 screener data from Qualtrics
The 'ratings' folder contains the scanned in goal and rumination ratings as well as an excel spreadsheet of the data

slides.name: Participant Log
description: Two separate versions of this with different data (one on SharePoint, the other on harddrive1)
Both files list the participant number and the participant condition (either UV UM RV RM)
The harddrive version 'Participant Log' is password protected because is contains participants contact details
The Sharepoint version 'Participants' is separated by included/excluded and includes log of preprocessing progress

slides.name: Backing up data
description: At the end of the day, all raw data from the EEG and psychophys computer needs uploading to sharepoint
The ratings need inputting into the excel file on sharepoint and the hard copy needs scanning in (there is a back log of this)
The paper hard copies are stored in the cabinet in the MDC group office
For more information see the separate tutorial

slides.name: Getting starting with Sona
description: The following information details how to login and navigate around SONA
After this, see separate tutorial for bulk granting credits for the screener survey.
Click 'Next' to get started

slides.name: Logging in
description: Input login details
Click 'Log in'
Click 'Researcher'

slides.name: Main screen
description: This is the main screen
Well labelled main page of interest is 'My Studies'
You can also confirm timings of participants under 'Upcoming Appointments'

slides.name: My Studies
description: The initial screen is for 'Active' surveys only
The active study is called *2.5 credits* Mood, Concentration and Problem solving
A second study is also used to grant credits for part 1 only which is under 'Inactive' surveys called *0.5 Credits* Mood, Concentration and Problem solving Survey

slides.name: Adding timeslots
description: You can add individual slots using the 'Add A Timeslot' button
You can also add multiple slots at once using the 'Add Multiple Timeslots' (see next page)
There are also buttons to delete slots if you make a mistake
Be careful with this there is nothing to stop you creating duplicate slots at the same time

slides.name: Adding multiple timeslots
description: Clicking 'Add Multiple Timeslots' brings you to this screen
If you are testing at the same times each week, there is a useful option to copy timeslots from week to week
There is a screen to confirm you are happy with the times before adding them

slides.name: Timeslot information
description: Clicking on an individual timeslot brings you to this screen
Most signups the participant signs themselves up although sometimes they may want to re-arrange
You can manually sign a person up on this screen by adding either their username (uni email) or name
You can also use this to add participants to the inactive survey to grant them 0.5 credits for the Qualtrics survey

slides.name: Granting credits
description: Clicking 'View your uncredited timeslots' brings you a list of participants
Your options here are to grant credits (2.5) or to report no-shows
You also have the 'Mark all 'Participated'' option for granting credits to multiple participants
Ensure you click 'Process changes' to save
